fields.description:
Consider the following Source Repository Checkout task:

Repo 1: GitHub
Folder: Parent

Repo 2: SVN
Folder: Parent/Child1

Repo 3: GitHub
Folder: Parent/Child2

The task will checkout the repos in the following order:

Repo 3
Repo 1
Repo 2

This results in the checkout of Repo 3 being deleted and the subsequent tasks that work on it failing.
fields.summary: Bamboo should finish "Force Clean Build" operation before it starts doing the checkouts.

fields.description: If I have user@domain.com the IM address validation passes, but it fails if I configure user@domain
fields.summary: IM notification validation fails if domain name doesn't have .com at the end

fields.description:
Hi,

we are using the following scenario, all our source is on a single repository but we split our code in main trunk into folders per technology (trunk/db, trunk/web, trunk/c, trunk/java):

- database is built on stage 1
- web, c++, java are built on stage 2 in parallel on a pool of compilation machines
- tests run on stage 3
- deployments on stages 4,5,6.

The problem is if we want to recreate the artifacts by running a build for a specific revision only the default repository definition uses the custom revision the rest are updated to head.

Due to the size of the code we cannot checkout full trunk on each build server and use default repository everywhere, we need a way to filter out database code and ansi c code from the web servers, or web and c from database.

Regards,
Iulius
fields.summary: Build custom revision not working across all repositories definitions even if they point to one repository

fields.description:
The recent addition of the ability to disable tasks within a job creates a semantic difference in the enable/disable logic;

Jobs have a checkbox, on by default, called 'Job Enabled'. Tasks have a checkbox, off by default, called 'Disable this task'

Absolutely minor, and possibly a tested UX interaction (each may make more sense in its respective context) but the variance struck me as questionable.

Unifying the enable/disable semantics might lead to a better overall experience.

Just my 2 cents.
fields.summary: Jobs are positively enabled, tasks are positively disabled

fields.description:
Currently, there's a mechanism for disabling a particular branch plan, but there's no way to disable the main plan to give preference to a branch; in the case of a hotfix, where code may be pushed into both development and a hotfix branch contemporaneously, being able to disable the develop branch to give precedence to the hotfix branch would make a significant difference in the time to test-completion if there's contention for agents.

The only way it seems this is possible now is to wait for the develop lines to kick off and then manually stop them, which is less than ideal.
fields.summary: Provide mechanism to disable main plan but allow branches to run

fields.description:
Currently, when you create a plan, the permissions are just for you (the person who created it). It would be great from an admin point to establish a permissions template that each plan could use.

It is similar to the project template concept that jira already has.
fields.summary: Create a global permissions template for a plan

fields.description: See the attachment.

Having a log viewer widget embedded with the job summary would be nice.

Could please suggest how to configure Android project for continuous integration with Bamboo?
Android is an open source I,download code and want to integrate with Bamboo,could you please support?

I am raising this task to keep track of all the documentation pages that you think should be update, corrected or added (new ones).

Please list all the pages that you find.

fields.description:
Bamboo says that the variables weren't included in the meta data because no custom variables were used during execution of the build. This would make sense if the plan configuration variables didn't change over time. 

Plan variables should be included in the build metadata regardless of whether "Run customized" option was used so that if I look at an old build I know what the plan configuration variables were set to when it was executed. This was how an older version of Bamboo functioned.
fields.summary: build metadata doesn't include variables which change over time

fields.description:
Please add the pages [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Repository+triggers+the+build+when+changes+are+committed] for Bitbucket and GitHub triggering builds.

Also, add information [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Triggering+builds] related triggering plan branches (they basically can be triggered the same way as regular plans).
fields.summary: Add documentaion pages for Bitbucket and GitHub triggering a Bamboo plans and branches

fields.description:
Artifactory plugin does some calls to APIs that should not be used.
It reopens logs without flushing the old data. There's a workaround for this issue in 4.4.2.
fields.summary: Logs are partially missing on Bamboo 4.4/4.4.1 when using Artifactory plugin

fields.description:
We have many global variables in JBAC, but some are redundant with each other and others we have mainly because we are unsure where they are used, don't want to remove them in case it breaks something (especially infrequently used builds).

It would be great if there was a screen which I could go to and enter a variable and Bamboo would tell me which plans use that variable.
fields.summary: I'd like to be able to see where a variable is used

fields.description:
Currently, we have a wallboard displaying the status of our plans : green, everything is fine, red, someone broke something.
This is really great.
It would be absolutely great to have the same kind of feature for agents, allowing us to know fast what agents are online and what agent went offline, on what plan they are working ...
fields.summary: Wallboard for agents status

fields.description:
I'm having problems copying files to the network, because of permission issues.  And it would be nice to be able to run the scripts as a particular user. i.e.

DOMAIN/user
pwd: ****
fields.summary: Bamboo inline / file scripts should have the option to Run as.

fields.description:
In older versions of Bamboo(Ex.Bamboo 2.6.3), when a defined artifact was missing after the build, there was a place for it in the artifact list of build results. The missing artifact was listed but not downloadable, so the customer knew an expected artifact was missing.

With Bamboo 4.4, when a defined artifact is missing, there is no indication outside of the build log that it is missing. The missing artifact is omitted from the build results artifact list.

It's possible to create a script task to check for each expected artifact and fail the build if the file is missing, but the old way is preferable since artifacts were only defined once.
fields.summary: List expected missing artifacts as missing in the build results artifact list

fields.description:
Variables in Bamboo can only be assigned one default value.
Parameterized builds will let us override these default values, however if environment variables had multiple default values - then users won't have to manually enter overriding value.
fields.summary: Multiple defaults for variables when executing parameterized builds

fields.description:
I'm trying to checkout my pom.xml update the version then submit the file. The Task "Source Code Checkout" using perforce works fine.  Both the Server and agent are running Windows Server 2008 sp1.  With perforce installed on both machine with Environment variable set in the Register.  So I'm a little confused when I have a brain dead script "p4 edit pom.xml"  called at the correct level.  And I receive the following error message:

Perforce client error:
        Connect to server failed; check $P4PORT.
        TCP connect to perforce:1666 failed.
        No such host is known. 

Which looks a lot like BAM-2321.  Which was resolved in 2008.  Any help towards resolving this would be welcome.
fields.summary: Bamboo cannot find Perforce configuration on agents.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

- Go to Plan Configuration -> Branches, and tick "Automatically manage branches"
- Push a new branch to the GitHub remote repository which is configured in the "Source Repositories" section of the plan
- Wait a few minutes, and Bamboo will detect the new branch. After 5 minutes Bamboo will add the same (duplicate) branch again (and again,..).
fields.summary: The same GitHub repository branches get detected and added every time the detection runs

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce*
# Look at build #1 (assuming it is failing), assign responsibility to John Doe. It takes as is expected.
# Look at build #2 (assuming it is failing), assign responsibility to Jane Doe. It takes as is expected.
# Reload the build page for build #1, and it now shows Jane Doe as being responsible.

This does not affect earlier failed builds that have been fixed before build #1 and #2.
fields.summary: Assigning responsibility on one failed build changes responsibilities on all broken builds

fields.description:
This concerns the SCP and SSH tasks plugin.

After a succesfull run of a command by SSH the command completes correctly by the sshd process on the remote server never exits.

Also see Atlassian Answers: Bamboo SCP/SSH Task - Hanging sshd connections on remote agent.

As far as I can see it both in SshTask.java and in ScpTask.java a connection is build to a (remote) sshd with "ssh.connect(host, portNumber);". "ssh" being a "SSHClient" object.

This connection is never (properly) disconnected with a corresponding "ssh.disconnect".

This might cause the described behaviour.
fields.summary: Hanging sshd connections on remote server

fields.description: Make editing/managing environment, plan and task variables more user-friendly. Allow the user to have full control over all variables. For example, allow a user to configure a specific set of environment variables (custom) to be applied to all tasks (or to a group of tasks) in a plan.
fields.summary: Make the Bamboo variables exportable with a custom Environment variable name

fields.description:
With the release of Grails 2.2.0, having it available in the stock images would help users with builds without requiring an EBS volume.

The current Grails on the stock images is 2.1.1
fields.summary: Update Grails to 2.2.0 on Ec2 images

fields.description:
I'm working on replicating the issue, but to wit:

We upgraded to 4.4 a week ago, and have branch detection for several Github-based projects checking for (release)/.* 

Noticed that when I branched to release/february, the auto-detect picked up the branch, but had the actual Github branch set to develop, not the release branch, and more strangely, seemed to be picking up multiple copies of the same branch (release-february, release-february 1, release-february 2, release-february 3, etc.)

I saw at least 8 branches get created before I turned off the auto-detection, so unsure whether this was an issue with cross-branch merges I was doing, commits to the branch, etc. 

As noted above, I'm working on replicating this more thoroughly. Also wondering if this might be related to BAM-12770 and that the bamboo/github integration is out of date.

Just recording the issue for posterity.
fields.summary: Auto-branch detection with Github seems problematic in 4.4

fields.description: Technically, not a bug, or even really an issue, just sorta a ???? Obviously, for Flash-less systems, selecting the text and using the system to C&P is easy, but this just seems like a weird addition to an otherwise pure-HTML front-end.
fields.summary: Bamboo 4.4 copy and paste functionality is Flash based

fields.description:
If branch A is created as PLANKEY0 and branch B is created as PLANKEY1, and then branch A is deleted, branch C will be created as PLANKEY0. This leads to broken and out of date links to branch artifacts, etc.

Until branch plan naming can be specified, would it at least be possible to have the branch plan key increment be permanently unique and increasing?
fields.summary: Bamboo branch plan keys are reused

fields.description: This would increase Bamboo resilience and  let us hot patch OnDemand without restarting the instance.
fields.summary: Deleted classpath.zip should regenerate itself

fields.description:
Bamboo 4.4 and 4.4.1 shipped with a version of UPM (2.7.8) whose self-update functionality is broken. This is a key part of UPM as it gets new UPM updates to customers - and nobody with 4.4 or 4.4.1 will be able to update their UPM version without dropping the jar into their plugins directory and restarting the app.

This is fixed in UPM 2.7.10. Even more preferable would be to bump to UPM 2.8.1 as this brings in many improvements and new features plus ADG-compatibility.
fields.summary: UPM cannot self-update in Bamboo 4.4 and 4.4.1

fields.description: Without having to write a plugin to wire into the branch creation process, having an option to auto-execute a script when a branch is created would enable any specific branch-plan changes that needed to occur happen before the branch was enabled; I'm thinking specifically of a script that could update branch variables, change notification settings, permissions, etc.
fields.summary: Provide mechanism for "on branch creation" scripts to be executed

fields.description:
The jenkins importer is awesome but, unfortunately for me, does not work for recent versions of hudson. Shortly after the hudson/jenkins split at V1.39, the config format changed in hudson meaning that a separate importer for hudson is needed (or extra logic added to the existing jenkins importer).

A suggested alternative option was to upgrade from hudson to jenkins and then import to bamboo, this does not work for the same reason the bamboo jenkins importer does not. It was also suggested to try a downgrade to hudson 1.39 to enable the jenkins migration then use the bamboo importer but this is not possible.
fields.summary: import configuration from hudson

fields.description:
The red error box shows up, i go edit the plan to fix the problem, then i want to rerun.  But I can't its disabled.  

The fact that the plan got disabled should be mentioned in the red message box so its at least not a surprise.  Or I can potentially discover why it happened.
fields.summary: If we disable a plan due to repo failure we should add this to the error message.

fields.description: The message is a bit out of context and those sort of messages have the tendency to confuse.  No point causing confusion for no reason...
fields.summary: Warning about changing repo could break branch config should at least check if you have any branches
Builds get stuck in queue if capable agents become available after the build is queued

fields.summary: I want to see if a branch plan is building on the All Plans page, not only the root plan.

fields.description:
The Labels Service allows you to see all builds with a specific label, such as "release":

[http://bamboo/browse/label/release]

However, if there are a lot of labeled builds and a lot of plans within a project, this does not help a person find the latest "release" build for a specific plan.  Adding a REST endpoint to do this would be helpful:

[http://bamboo/browse/PROJECTKEY-PLANKEY/label/release]
fields.summary: Extend Labels Service REST API to List Specific Plan Builds by Label

fields.description: We were unable to find a document that explains the Audit Log feature in Bamboo.(Adminstration->System->Audit Log). When it gets enabled an Audit Log tab gets added in the configuration page for each plan. Certain type of information gets recorded in the "Global Configuration Change History" page and different types of information at the "Plan Level". It will be great to have a detailed, clear document for this feature.
fields.summary: Missing Documentation for the "Audit Log" feature

fields.description:
For example, if I define a plan variable 'VAR' having value 'val' and in a script task call a command 'env' to print all the environment variables, Bamboo attached 'bamboo_' prefix to the plan variable and shows it in the environment variables list:
{code}
..
... using extra environment variables: \nbamboo_VAR=val
..
build	07-Feb-2013 13:45:57	SHELL=/bin/bash
build	07-Feb-2013 13:45:57	TERM=xterm-256color
build	07-Feb-2013 13:45:57	MAVEN_OPTS=-Xmx512m
build	07-Feb-2013 13:45:57	bamboo_VAR=val
...
{code}

By the way, when I try to use the variable by calling ${bamboo.VAR} from the same script task, it works just fine.

This behavior is by design that Bamboo Variables can be used as environment variables. Users can substitute variables in configuration fields.
fields.summary: Bamboo plan variables get prefixed with 'bamboo_' and get into the environment variables list

fields.description:
If you are shown the screen when ADDING a new task. The delete link shows, but does not work
Probably should hide delete link and have a cancel link.  When editing task could also do with a cancel link.
This bug is pretty minor -> chances of users hitting this screen is quite low.

Slightly higher chance of occurring: If you do hit the delete link when you are EDITING as task, the dialog does not go away, and the red message also does not go away, leaving you with a very broken looking screen
fields.summary: Invalid task plugin screen bugginess

fields.description: You check the checkbox, the value is not saved

When Bamboo removes the Plan Branch it should optionally also remove the branch in Git/Mercurial

fields.description:
The artifacts and build logs don't get expired based on the settings in the build expiry page(Plans->Build Expiry). As you can see from the screenshots I have set it up to delete all build logs and artifacts in 1 day, except the ones that have the "releasetest" label. But it doesn't remove any at the scheduled time(4:40pm- in my test environment). Looking at the logs it says that It's deleting some expired build logs but when I look at the folders none of them are deleted.
I have attached screenshots that shows my settings in 4.4.0, folders holding the artifacts and build logs that have stayed the same as before the scheduled expiry task runs and Bamboo's log file.

fields.description:
The maven dependency processor fails with the error below if we use variable paths:

{noformat}
Automatic Maven plan dependencies processing failed: org.apache.maven.project.ProjectBuildingException: Some problems were encountered while processing the POMs:
	[ERROR] 'dependencies.dependency.systemPath' for java:plugin.jar:jar must specify an absolute path but is ${java.home}\lib\plugin.jar @ line 23, column 16
	
05-Feb-2013 18:39:30 	Finished task 'Maven Dependencies Processor'
{noformat}

Basically I replicate the issue by adding the below dependency to my pom.xml and configuring the processor task:
{code}
<dependency>
<groupId>java</groupId>
<artifactId>plugin.jar</artifactId>
<systemPath>${java.home}/lib/plugin.jar</systemPath>
<version>$
{java.version}
</version>
<scope>system</scope>
</dependency>
{code}

Substituting java.home with the absolute path fixes the issue. Again running the command *mvn help:effective-pom* from DOS does indeed substituted correctly.
fields.summary: The Maven dependency processor not able to expand paths

fields.description: Agents started using the elasticagentinstaller seem to have a fixed max heap size of {{256m}}. This seems to be a hardcoded default in {{/components/bamboo-agent-elastic-installer/src/main/java/com/atlassian/bamboo/agent/elastic/installer/ElasticAgentInstaller.java}} , and can cause problems for plans that have a large number of test results to return as they OOM and put the agent in a bad state.
fields.summary: There is no way to change the heap size for elastic agents that are started using the ElasticAgentInstaller

fields.description:
There is a widespread Linux security practice to set the /tmp directory with "noexec" set. Because Bamboo proxies all SSH requests through /tmp/bamboo-ssh.9900a68e.sh, if the /tmp directory is set to noexec, Bamboo defaults to JGit. JGit is unreliable as a Git implementation, as it is slow and also changes the repository contents when cloning - for example, symlinks are cloned as flat files.

As I understand it, the push with Bamboo is to move away from JGit. However, doing so and also keeping /tmp/bamboo-ssh.9900a68e.sh hard-coded to /tmp will lead to problems with people who have secured /tmp, but need to use native Git.

This ticket is a suggestion to include a configurable property (either through the UI, or just directly in setenv.sh or bamboo.properties) where we can set the location of /tmp. This will allow us to keep our /tmp directory secured, yet not prevent Bamboo from using the native Git.
fields.summary: Include the Ability to Configure the Directory Location where Bamboo expects /tmp

fields.description:
Child plans created from automatic branch creation inherit everything from the parent. It would be very useful to be able to mark tasks "inheritable" in the parent plan, with the purpose of being able to prevent certain tasks from being run.

The use case is that for example: A customer wants to have a plan that calls a "deploy" task at the end, but they don't have any branches automatically created from that build plan to also be deployed. This, of course, can be done by going into the child plan and removing the task, but it would be much more useful to be able to configure the behavior of the plan at the start and not have to manually update plans as they are created.
fields.summary: Override or Remove Tasks defined by Parent Plan in Bamboo in Automatically Created Branch Plans

fields.description:
Observed behavior is that Bamboo is performing export (for example scheduled export) and after some time later Bamboo pauses itself.

Steps to reproduce:
0) have empty Bamboo instance (no running plans, etc)
1) create a plan with a script task "sleep 10d"
2) run that plan - it will run infinitely
3) administration->export->run export, wait for it to finish (Bamboo for a while will be in PAUSING state)
4) bamboo will get back to RUNNING state
5) stop your running plan
6a) bamboo becomes "PAUSED"
6b) while we would expect no pause would occur
fields.summary: Exporting while Bamboo is executing at least one plan results in Bamboo unintentional pausing.

Task: Add a new repository. A git repo on stash.a.c with a custom branch.

This has many problems...

I have a reference repo that I am copying. It claims it is a "Git" repo as the Source Repository field. BUG1: It should report "stash master on stash.a.c"

When not knowing this, selecting Git and filling in the appropriate fields then clicking save, apparently has no affect. BUG2: Validation errors not visible but are hidden in the advanced disclosure. BUG3: No visual clue is given that the operation failed. BUG4: Navigating to another location in the UI does not warn that config will be lost(I did this and had to start again).

On finally checking the Source Repository drop-down and figuring out that it was a shared repository...BUG5: Config of shared repos is only available to admin users(which luckily I am one).

BUG6: It *should* be possible to override fields of a shared repo. In particular the branch.

I'm suggesting the UX could be improved here somewhat.

fields.description:
It appears that to get proper oauth handling exception handling you MUST use a ApplicationLinkResponseHandler.

Which I think is complete crap and every execute method should identify oauth errors correctly and throw the CredentialsRequiredException where appropriate.  So whilst I'm calling this a bug/design flaw in oauth, we can fix it by changing the response handler.

Fisheye are also suffering this problem.  Presumably they will chase it up with the oauth guys.
fields.summary: Create Issue does not handle oauth exceptions correctly

fields.description:
When a spot EC2 instance is provisioned, and the price increases dramatically between the bid submission and the actual spinup, Bamboo reflects the current spot price as opposed to the price at which the instance was obtained at.

Ideally it should be an accurate reflection of the spot price, failing which it should show the maximum bid as opposed to the current spot price to avoid unnecessary heart attacks.
fields.summary: Spot instance prices can sometimes be inaccurate

{noformat}

This happens when you have a shallow clone and the branch on the origin repository gets force-updated (for instance force-push). When that happens, the origin repository does not have the commits that the shallow clone says it has and cannot calculate what objects to send over the wire.
fields.summary: Fetches for shallow clones for git repositories occasionally cause "fatal: did not find object for shallow <commit-hash>" error

fields.description:
on this [page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Using+global%2C+plan+or+build-specific+variables] we advertise the existence of _buildForceCleanCheckout_ built-in variable. I cannot manage Bamboo to substitute that variable (probably we cut it off at some point). So we probably should either restore it, or update the CAC documentation.

Bonus points for fixing the [VariableSubstitutionTest testBuiltInVariablesDoSub|http://tardigrade.dyn.syd.atlassian.com:8085/bamboo/browse/BAM-FC-8845] FT, accordingly to the resolution of this issue.
fields.summary: Do something about ${bamboo.buildForceCleanCheckout} variable.
Duplicate plan key errors should show a warning at the top of the page more clearly

fields.description:
See CCD-CLMVN-JOB1 on BEAC:

!bambo_ficzer.png!

I'm not 100% sure how to reproduce it. I did steps like these:

1) I had a job with a requirement to the 'maven 2.1' executable and a 'maven 2.x' task in the job using this 'maven 2.1' executable for build.

2) I added new 'maven 2.2.1' requirement on the list of requirements (Add extra requirement)

Thus I had two Mavens on the list:
 * maven 2.1 required by maven 2.x task
 * maven 2.2.1 as extra requirement

3) Next, I updated the 'maven 2.x' task to use new 'maven 2.2.1' executable

4) When I switched to list of requirement, the 'maven 2.1' disappeared, but the table began to be distorted as on screen shot above. 

Cheers
Marek
fields.summary: Corrupted table on Requirements tab
